photos.alt: Summer Tanager (Piranga rubra) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Summer Tanager is one of the few completely red birds in North America. This brilliant male was foraging in the canopy in Kerr County. Their diet consists primarily of bees and wasps, which they catch in flight and remove the stinger before eating.

photos.alt: Summer Tanager (Piranga rubra) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Male Summer Tanager in breeding plumage. The males are entirely bright red while females are olive-yellow.

photos.alt: Summer Tanager (Piranga rubra) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Summer Tanagers primarily eat large flying insects, especially bees and wasps.

photos.alt: Summer Tanager (Piranga rubra) - Female | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Female Summer Tanager showing the characteristic olive-yellow coloration that distinguishes it from the all-red male.

photos.alt: Golden-cheeked Warbler (Setophaga chrysoparia) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Golden-cheeked Warbler is an endangered species that breeds only in the mature juniper-oak woodlands of central Texas. I spent several hours searching for this striking male in Kerr County during breeding season.

photos.alt: Vermilion Flycatcher (Pyrocephalus rubinus) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Vermilion Flycatcher is arguably one of the most striking birds in North America. This brilliantly colored male was perched prominently on a fence post, making occasional sallies to catch flying insects.

photos.alt: Vermilion Flycatcher (Pyrocephalus rubinus) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Male Vermilion Flycatcher in breeding plumage showing its brilliant red coloration that stands out against any background.

photos.alt: Vermilion Flycatcher (Pyrocephalus rubinus) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: This male Vermilion Flycatcher repeatedly returned to the same perch after catching flying insects, allowing for excellent photography opportunities.

photos.alt: Vermilion Flycatcher (Pyrocephalus rubinus) - Female | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Female Vermilion Flycatcher showing the peach-colored underparts instead of the bright red seen in males.

photos.alt: Painted Bunting (Passerina ciris) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Painted Bunting is often called the most beautiful bird in North America, and it's easy to see why. This male's vibrant blue head, red underparts, and green back make it look like it was colored by a child with crayons.

photos.alt: Painted Bunting (Passerina ciris) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Male Painted Bunting in breeding plumage. These colorful birds spend much of their time concealed in dense vegetation.

photos.alt: Painted Bunting (Passerina ciris) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The striking combination of blue, green, and red in the male Painted Bunting makes it one of the most vividly colored birds in North America.

photos.alt: Painted Bunting (Passerina ciris) - Female | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Female Painted Bunting. Unlike the vibrantly colored males, females are a uniform bright yellow-green that provides excellent camouflage.

photos.alt: Black-capped Vireo (Vireo atricapilla) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Black-capped Vireo is an endangered species that has very specific habitat requirements of scrubby oak and juniper. This male was singing persistently from the edge of a clearing in Kerr County.

photos.alt: Scott's Oriole (Icterus parisorum) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Scott's Orioles are striking birds of arid landscapes in the southwestern United States. Their yellow and black plumage provides a beautiful contrast against the dry landscape.

photos.alt: Baltimore Oriole (Icterus galbula) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: The Baltimore Oriole is known for its brilliant orange and black plumage. This male was foraging in the canopy of tall trees.

photos.alt: Indigo Bunting (Passerina cyanea) | Kerr County, TX
photos.description: Male Indigo Bunting in breeding plumage. These small birds appear almost entirely blue in good lighting.

photos.alt: Turquoise-browed Motmot (Eumomota superciliosa) | Guanacaste, Costa Rica
photos.description: The Turquoise-browed Motmot is known for its stunning colors and distinctive racket-shaped tail. I photographed this individual early in the morning at a resort in Guanacaste.

photos.alt: Rufous-naped Wren (Campylorhynchus rufinucha) | Guanacaste, Costa Rica
photos.description: Rufous-naped Wrens are large, social wrens found in Central America. This individual was part of a noisy family group moving through trees near my hotel in Costa Rica.

photos.alt: White-throated Magpie-Jay (Calocitta formosa) | Guanacaste, Costa Rica
photos.description: The White-throated Magpie-Jay is a striking blue and white jay species with a distinctive black-tipped crest. These intelligent birds are highly social and travel in family groups through the dry forests of Central America.

photos.alt: Great Kiskadee (Pitangus sulphuratus) | Guanacaste, Costa Rica
photos.description: The Great Kiskadee is a bold, vocal flycatcher with a black and white striped head pattern and bright yellow underparts. Their onomatopoeic "kis-ka-dee" call is a characteristic sound of Central and South America.

photos.alt: Northern Flicker (Colaptes auratus) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: Northern Flickers are woodpeckers with distinctive spotted plumage and bright yellow shaft feathers visible in flight. This individual was foraging on the ground at a Chicago park.

photos.alt: Downy Woodpecker (Picoides pubescens) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America. I found this male working its way up a tree trunk in a Chicago forest preserve.

photos.alt: Belted Kingfisher (Megaceryle alcyon) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: Belted Kingfishers are striking birds with their slate blue coloration and impressive crest. This female was perched above a stream, scanning for fish below.

photos.alt: Wood Duck (Aix sponsa) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: Wood Ducks are often considered the most beautiful waterfowl in North America. This male was swimming in a small pond in a Chicago park.

photos.alt: American Goldfinch (Spinus tristis) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: American Goldfinches are bright spots of color in summer when males like this one wear their brilliant yellow breeding plumage. I found this individual feeding on thistle seeds.

photos.alt: Rose-breasted Grosbeak (Pheucticus ludovicianus) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: The Rose-breasted Grosbeak is a stunning bird with its black and white plumage and distinctive rose-colored breast patch. This male visited a feeder in a Chicago backyard.

photos.alt: American Goldfinch (Spinus tristis) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: The American Goldfinch is a small North American bird in the finch family. This male in breeding plumage shows the brilliant yellow coloration that makes them one of our most recognizable songbirds.

photos.alt: Baltimore Oriole (Icterus galbula) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: The Baltimore Oriole is a striking black and orange member of the blackbird family. This adult male was photographed during spring migration in a Chicago park.

photos.alt: Black-and-white Warbler (Mniotilta varia) | Chicago, IL
photos.description: The Black-and-white Warbler is a distinctive warbler with bold black and white striped plumage. Unlike most warblers that forage among leaves, this species creeps along tree trunks and branches like a nuthatch.

photos.alt: Red-winged Blackbird (Agelaius phoeniceus) - Female | Chicago, IL
photos.description: Female Red-winged Blackbirds look quite different from the familiar black males with red shoulder patches. Females like this one are heavily streaked brown and white, resembling large sparrows.

photos.alt: Great Blue Heron (Ardea herodias) | Atlanta, GA
photos.description: Great Blue Herons are among the largest wading birds in North America. This majestic individual was stalking fish in a small pond in Atlanta.

photos.alt: Yellow-bellied Sapsucker (Sphyrapicus varius) | Atlanta, GA
photos.description: Yellow-bellied Sapsuckers create distinctive rows of holes in trees to collect sap. This woodpecker was working on a pattern of fresh holes in an Atlanta park.

photos.alt: Ruby-crowned Kinglet (Regulus calendula) | Atlanta, GA
photos.description: Ruby-crowned Kinglets are tiny, restless birds that rarely sit still. I was lucky to capture this one during a brief moment of stillness in an Atlanta park.

photos.alt: Hermit Thrush (Catharus guttatus) | Dallas, TX
photos.description: Hermit Thrushes are known for their beautiful, flute-like songs. I found this individual quietly hopping through leaf litter at the Trinity Audubon Center in Dallas.

photos.alt: Eastern Phoebe (Sayornis phoebe) | Dallas, TX
photos.description: Eastern Phoebes are early spring migrants and often one of the first flycatchers to return north. This bird was actively hunting from a low perch at Trinity Audubon Center.

photos.alt: Bald Eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) | Watersmeet, MI
photos.description: The Bald Eagle is America's national bird and a conservation success story. I photographed this adult eagle at a lake in Michigan's Upper Peninsula where it was perched in a tall pine.

photos.alt: Bananaquit (Coereba flaveola) | Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands
photos.description: The Bananaquit is a small, active nectar-feeder common throughout the Caribbean. This individual was feeding on hibiscus flowers near my hotel in Grand Cayman.

photos.alt: Cayman Parrot (Amazona leucocephala caymanensis) | Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands
photos.description: The Cayman Parrot is a subspecies of the Cuban Amazon parrot and is the national bird of the Cayman Islands. This individual was part of a noisy group feeding in a fruit tree.

photos.alt: Yellow-rumped Warbler (Setophaga coronata) | Los Angeles, CA
photos.description: Yellow-rumped Warblers are common throughout much of North America. This is the "Audubon's" form found in the western US, showing more yellow on the throat than eastern birds.

photos.alt: Anna's Hummingbird (Calypte anna) | Los Angeles, CA
photos.description: Anna's Hummingbird is a medium-sized hummingbird native to the west coast of North America. The male, shown here, has an iridescent crimson crown and throat (gorget) that can appear dark or brilliantly colored depending on the viewing angle.

photos.alt: Northern Mockingbird (Mimus polyglottos) | Los Angeles, CA
photos.description: The Northern Mockingbird is famous for its ability to mimic the songs of other birds and even mechanical sounds. This individual was photographed in a suburban setting where they often thrive.

photos.alt: Rock Wren (Salpinctes obsoletus) | Palm Springs, CA
photos.description: Rock Wrens inhabit arid rocky slopes throughout the western US. I found this individual hopping among boulders near Palm Springs, perfectly camouflaged against the rocky background.

photos.alt: Java Sparrow (Lonchura oryzivora) | Maui, HI
photos.description: Java Sparrows are not native to Hawaii but were introduced and have established populations on several islands. I found this group feeding on grass seeds in a Maui park.

photos.alt: Japanese White-eye (Zosterops japonicus) | Maui, HI
photos.description: The Japanese White-eye, also known as Warbling White-eye, is another introduced species that has established populations on most Hawaiian islands.

photos.alt: Japanese White-eye (Zosterops japonicus) | Maui, HI
photos.description: These small, active birds have a distinctive white eye-ring that gives them their common name. They're common in parks and gardens throughout Hawaii.

photos.alt: Common Myna (Acridotheres tristis) | Maui, HI
photos.description: Common Mynas were introduced to Hawaii in the late 1800s and are now abundant in urban and agricultural areas throughout the islands.

photos.alt: White-rumped Shama (Copsychus malabaricus) | Maui, HI
photos.description: The White-rumped Shama is known for its beautiful song and was introduced to Hawaii from southeast Asia. This striking bird is often seen perched in the mid-canopy.

photos.alt: Red-vented Bulbul (Pycnonotus cafer) | Honolulu, HI
photos.description: The Red-vented Bulbul is an introduced species in Hawaii, primarily found on Oahu. These bold birds have adapted well to urban environments.

photos.alt: Great Horned Owl (Bubo virginianus) | Ladybird Johnson Wildflower Center, Austin, TX
photos.description: This Great Horned Owl, known as Athena, has been returning to the same roosting location at the Ladybird Johnson Wildflower Center for over a decade. When photographed, she was guarding her owlets which weren't yet large enough to be visible.

photos.alt: Bewick's Wren (Thryomanes bewickii) | Ladybird Johnson Wildflower Center, Austin, TX
photos.description: The Bewick's Wren is a small but energetic songbird with a distinctive white eyebrow and long, upright tail. This individual was spotted carrying nesting material at the Ladybird Johnson Wildflower Center outside Austin.

photos.alt: Great Crested Flycatcher (Myiarchus crinitus) | Oak Brook, IL
photos.description: The Great Crested Flycatcher is a large insect-eating bird with a distinctive lemon-yellow belly and rufous tail. This woodland species is more often heard than seen, with a loud, rising "wheep" call.

photos.alt: Scarlet Tanager (Piranga olivacea) | Eastern USA
photos.description: The Scarlet Tanager is a medium-sized American songbird with breeding males featuring brilliant red plumage and black wings and tail.

photos.alt: Ladder-backed Woodpecker (Dryobates scalaris) | Southwestern USA
photos.description: The Ladder-backed Woodpecker is a small woodpecker of arid regions featuring black and white barred back and wings that give it a ladder-like appearance.

photos.alt: Yellow-bellied Sapsucker (Sphyrapicus varius) | Eastern USA
photos.description: Yellow-bellied Sapsuckers are migratory woodpeckers known for drilling neat rows of holes in trees to feed on sap and insects attracted to it.

photos.alt: American Goldfinch (Spinus tristis) | North America
photos.description: The American Goldfinch is a small North American bird in the finch family. The male displays bright yellow plumage during the breeding season.

photos.alt: Belted Kingfisher (Megaceryle alcyon) | North America
photos.description: The Belted Kingfisher is a large, conspicuous water kingfisher commonly found near rivers and lakes throughout North America.
